message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Explosive Cooperation in Social Dilemmas on Higher-Order Networks
Paper Abstract: Understanding how cooperative behaviors can emerge from competitive interactions is an open problem in biology and social sciences. While interactions are usually modeled as pairwise networks, the units of many real-world systems can also interact in groups of three or more. Here, we introduce a general framework to extend pairwise games to higher-order networks. By studying social dilemmas on hypergraphs with a tunable structure, we find an explosive transition to cooperation triggered by a critical number of higher-order games. The associated bistable regime implies that an initial critical mass of cooperators is also required for the emergence of prosocial behavior. Our results show that higher-order interactions provide a novel explanation for the survival of cooperation. Published by the American Physical Society 2024
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about hypergraphs:

## Definition

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.(no content)In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.

## Key Characteristics

A hypergraph H is a pair (V, E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V called hyperedges. Each hyperedge may contain one or more vertices.

## Applications

Hypergraphs have diverse practical applications. Undirected hypergraphs are useful in modelling such things as satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems.(no content)Applications include recommender system (communities as hyperedges), image retrieval (correlations as hyperedges), and bioinformatics (biochemical interactions as hyperedges).

## Related Concepts

In computational geometry, an undirected hypergraph may sometimes be called a range space and then the hyperedges are called ranges.(no content)In cooperative game theory, hypergraphs are called simple games (voting games); this notion is applied to solve problems in social choice theory.

## Special Types

Different types of hypergraphs include:
- A k-uniform hypergraph where every edge consists of exactly k vertices
- A balanced hypergraph which is essentially 2-colorable, and remains essentially 2-colorable upon deleting any number of vertices

Hypergraph theory extends many classical graph theory concepts and is an active area of mathematical research with numerous theoretical and practical applications.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, "Social Dilemma" can refer to two different concepts:

## The Social Dilemma (Documentary)

The Social Dilemma centers on the social and cultural impact of social media usage on regular users, with a focus on algorithmically enabled forms of behavior modification and psychological manipulation.(no content)The film depicts an array of related themes, including technological addiction, fake news, depression, and anxiety.(no content)The Social Dilemma premiered at the 2020 Sundance Film Festival on January 26, 2020, and was released worldwide on Netflix on September 9, 2020. The documentary features interviews with tech industry insiders who discuss the negative impacts of social media algorithms.

## Social Dilemma (Academic Concept)

A collective action problem or social dilemma is a situation in which all individuals would be better off cooperating but fail to do so because of conflicting interests between individuals that discourage joint action.(no content)Social dilemmas can take many forms and are studied across disciplines such as psychology, economics, and political science.(no content)The prisoner's dilemma is a simple game that serves as the basis for research on social dilemmas. The premise of the game is that two partners in crime are imprisoned separately and each are offered leniency if they provide evidence against the other.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Algorithmic game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_game_theory"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Game Theory:

## What is Game Theory?

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

**Nash Equilibrium**: Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

**Game Types**: A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats).

## Modern Applications

It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.(no content)Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

Web search results for query: "Bistability Dynamical Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Bistability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bistability"},{"title":"Multistability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multistability"},{"title":"Biological applications of bifurcation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_applications_of_bifurcation_theory"},{"title":"Hopf bifurcation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopf_bifurcation"},{"title":"Bifurcation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bifurcation_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Bifurcation diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bifurcation_diagram"},{"title":"Bistable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bistable"},{"title":"Chaos theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_theory"}]

## Search Results for Bistability in Dynamical Systems

I've found comprehensive information about bistability in dynamical systems. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition
In a dynamical system, bistability means the system has two stable equilibrium states.(no content)A bistable structure can be resting in either of two states.

### Mathematical Foundation
In a conservative force field, bistability stems from the fact that the potential energy has two local minima, which are the stable equilibrium points.(no content)By mathematical arguments, a local maximum, an unstable equilibrium point, must lie between the two minima.

### Real-World Applications
Bistable behavior can occur in mechanical linkages, electronic circuits, nonlinear optical systems, chemical reactions, and physiological and biological systems.(no content)An example of a mechanical device which is bistable is a light switch.

### Digital Electronics
Bistability is widely used in digital electronics devices to store binary data. It is the essential characteristic of the flip-flop, a circuit which is a fundamental building block of computers and some types of semiconductor memory.

### Biological Systems
Bistability can also arise in biochemical systems, where it creates digital, switch-like outputs from the constituent chemical concentrations and activities.(no content)Bistability can only arise in biological and chemical systems if three necessary conditions are fulfilled: positive feedback, a mechanism to filter out small stimuli and a mechanism to prevent increase without bound.

### Hysteresis
Bistability is often accompanied by hysteresis.

Links: [{"title":"Complex network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_network"},{"title":"Complex Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_Networks"},{"title":"Climate as complex networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_as_complex_networks"},{"title":"Robustness of complex networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_of_complex_networks"},{"title":"Journal of Complex Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Complex_Networks"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Supply chain network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Macroprogramming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroprogramming"}]

Here are the search results for "Complex Networks":

## Scientific Definition

In network theory, a complex network is a graph (network) with non-trivial topological features—features that do not occur in simple networks such as lattices or random graphs but often occur in networks representing real systems.(no content)The study of complex networks is a young and active area of scientific research (since 2000) inspired largely by empirical findings of real-world networks such as computer networks, biological networks, technological networks, brain networks, climate networks and social networks.

## Key Characteristics

Most social, biological, and technological networks display substantial non-trivial topological features, with patterns of connection between their elements that are neither purely regular nor purely random, including a heavy tail in the degree distribution, a high clustering coefficient, assortativity or disassortativity among vertices, community structure, and hierarchical structure.

## Important Network Types

Two well-known and much studied classes of complex networks are scale-free networks and small-world networks, characterized by specific structural features—power-law degree distributions for the former and short path lengths and high clustering for the latter.

## Interdisciplinary Applications

The field continues to develop at a brisk pace, and has brought together researchers from many areas including mathematics, physics, electric power systems, biology, climate, computer science, sociology, epidemiology, and others.(no content)Ideas and tools from network science and engineering have been applied to the analysis of metabolic and genetic regulatory networks; the study of ecosystem stability and robustness; clinical science; the modeling and design of scalable communication networks; and a broad range of other practical issues.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Cooperation Biology Evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_Aid:_A_Factor_of_Evolution"},{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Coevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coevolution"},{"title":"Microbial cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of cooperation in biology and evolution:

## What is Cooperation in Evolution?

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)It is commonly defined as any adaptation that has evolved, at least in part, to increase the reproductive success of the actor's social partners.

## The Evolutionary Puzzle

Prominent biologists, such as Charles Darwin, E. O. Wilson, and W. D. Hamilton, have found the evolution of cooperation fascinating because natural selection favors those who achieve the greatest reproductive success while cooperative behavior often decreases the reproductive success of the actor. Hence, cooperation seemed to pose a challenging problem to the theory of natural selection, which rests on the assumption that individuals compete to survive and maximize their reproductive successes.

## How Cooperation Evolves

There have been multiple hypotheses for the evolution of cooperation, all of which are rooted in Hamilton's models based on inclusive fitness. These models hypothesize that cooperation is favored by natural selection due to either direct fitness benefits (mutually beneficial cooperation) or indirect fitness benefits (altruistic cooperation).(no content)In evolutionary biology, five mechanisms for the evolution of cooperation have been suggested: (i) kin selection, (ii) direct reciprocity, (iii) indirect reciprocity, (iv) spatial structure, and (v) group selection.

## Cooperation Across Species

Cooperation exists not only in humans but in other animals as well. The diversity of taxa that exhibits cooperation is quite large, ranging from zebra herds to pied babblers to African elephants. Additionally, in microbial systems, cells belonging to the same taxa have been documented partaking in cooperative interactions to perform a wide range of complex multicellular behaviors such as dispersal, foraging, construction of biofilms, reproduction, chemical warfare, and signaling.

Based on the search results, I found that the results mostly relate to network architecture and topology concepts, but don't directly address "Higher-Order Networks" as a specific research topic. Let me search more specifically for this term in an academic context.

Links: [{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_deep_learning"},{"title":"Topology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topology"},{"title":"Order topology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_topology"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Topological data analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_data_analysis"},{"title":"Hierarchical network model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_network_model"},{"title":"Network topology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_topology"},{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"Hypercube internetwork topology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypercube_internetwork_topology"},{"title":"Geometric graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_graph_theory"}]

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about higher-order networks in the context of topological deep learning and network science. Here's what I found:

## Higher-Order Networks

Higher-order networks incorporate topological concepts to process data with higher-order relationships, such as interactions among multiple entities and complex hierarchies, leveraging structures like simplicial complexes and hypergraphs to capture global dependencies and qualitative spatial properties.(no content)Unlike traditional graphs where edges can only model binary relations among entities, higher-order relations incorporate more than two entities, allowing for a broader range of neighborhood functions to be defined to capture multi-way interactions among entities.

### Applications in Topological Deep Learning

Topological neural networks (TNNs), which are specialized architectures designed to operate on data structured in topological domains, are adept at handling intricate data representations such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, allowing them to capture both local and global relationships.

### Key Structures

Several topological domains are used to represent higher-order networks:
- Simplicial complexes represent the simplest form of higher-order domains that extend graph-based models and admit hierarchical structures suitable for various applications.
- Cell complexes generalize simplicial complexes while providing more flexibility in defining higher-order relations.
- Hypergraphs allow arbitrary set-type relations among entities where relations are not imposed by other relations, providing more flexibility.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about higher-order networks in the context of topological deep learning and network science. Here's what I found:

## Higher-Order Networks

Higher-order networks incorporate topological concepts to process data with higher-order relationships, such as interactions among multiple entities and complex hierarchies, leveraging structures like simplicial complexes and hypergraphs to capture global dependencies and qualitative spatial properties.(no content)Unlike traditional graphs where edges can only model binary relations among entities, higher-order relations incorporate more than two entities, allowing for a broader range of neighborhood functions to be defined to capture multi-way interactions among entities.

### Applications in Topological Deep Learning

Topological neural networks (TNNs), which are specialized architectures designed to operate on data structured in topological domains, are adept at handling intricate data representations such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, allowing them to capture both local and global relationships.

### Key Structures

Several topological domains are used to represent higher-order networks:
- Simplicial complexes represent the simplest form of higher-order domains that extend graph-based models and admit hierarchical structures suitable for various applications.
- Cell complexes generalize simplicial complexes while providing more flexibility in defining higher-order relations.
- Hypergraphs allow arbitrary set-type relations among entities where relations are not imposed by other relations, providing more flexibility.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what I've done:

## Summary

I've successfully extracted and classified the triples from the paper "Explosive Cooperation in Social Dilemmas on Higher-Order Networks":

**Paper Type:** `contribution` - The paper introduces a novel framework for extending pairwise games to higher-order networks.

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Game theory** (uses) - The paper extends pairwise games to higher-order networks, building on game-theoretic foundations.

2. **Social dilemma** (uses) - The core problem being studied: how cooperation emerges from competitive interactions.

3. **Hypergraph** (proposes) - The new mathematical structure for modeling higher-order interactions beyond traditional pairwise networks.

4. **Cooperation (evolution)** (uses) - Addresses the fundamental biological/social science problem the paper investigates.

5. **Complex network** (uses) - Extends network theory beyond simple pairwise interactions to study complex topologies.

6. **Bistability** (proposes) - The novel finding of a bistable regime where cooperation exhibits two stable equilibrium states.

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed! The JSON is properly formatted with valid Wikipedia URLs and all required fields.

Sources:
- [Game theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory)

- [Hypergraph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph)
- [Cooperation (evolution)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution))
- [Complex network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_network)
